comparison.title: AWS vs Azure for Private SaaS
comparison.overview: Private SaaS deployments require dedicated infrastructure, strong compliance controls, and reliable networking. Both AWS and Azure offer compelling solutions, each with distinct strengths.

platform.name: AWS

strengths.item: AWS Outposts for on-premises private deployments
Mature Marketplace for ISV SaaS distribution
Superior container support via EKS and ECS
Granular IAM for fine-grained access control

weaknesses.item: Complex pricing model can lead to cost surprises
Steeper learning curve for enterprise teams

platform.best_for: Startups and tech-native SaaS vendors needing flexibility and scale

platform.name: Azure

strengths.item: Deep Microsoft ecosystem integration (Active Directory, M365)
Azure Arc for hybrid and multi-cloud private deployments
Azure Private Link for secure SaaS network connectivity
Preferred by enterprise and government customers

weaknesses.item: Some services lag AWS in maturity and features
Support quality can be inconsistent at lower tiers

platform.best_for: Enterprise SaaS vendors targeting corporate or regulated industries

key_considerations.consideration: Azure leads for regulated industries; AWS is competitive but requires more configuration.
Both offer private endpoints and VPC/VNet isolation; Azure Private Link is simpler for SaaS tenancy.
AWS is flexible but complex; Azure enterprise agreements often yield better pricing for large organizations.
AWS offers robust isolation via accounts and VPCs; Azure uses subscriptions and resource groups.

comparison.verdict: Choose AWS for technical agility and broad service breadth. Choose Azure for enterprise integration, compliance-heavy markets, and Microsoft-centric customer bases.
